deck: Gregory "Greg" Arkin was a reclusive teenager at Smallville High who dedicated his time to collecting insects. He gained insectoid abilities after kryptonite-infected bugs swarm him. He was defeated by Clark Kent. Years later, Greg regained his sanity.
description: Greg Arkin was one of the meteor freaks of Smallville. After he was bitten by green kryptonite-infected bugs, he gained bug-like abilities. At first he was a villain of Clark Kent but 10 years later, Greg returned and declared that Clark is a hero who saved his life.
name: Greg Arkin

deck: Part of the LMD Zodiac team.
description:
After the "death" of the first Pisces LMD, Scorpio created a second version of the Pisces LMD. This version of Pisces, along with the other members of the Zodiac LMD's, joined under Quicksilver during his bout with temporary insanity to battle the Avengers for their imagined wrongdoings.

Pisces joined Aquarius, Capricorn and Sagittarius at the "Ant-Hill", an abandoned Sentinel factory. Pisces ended up facing off against Thor, and was destroyed when Thor crushed it beneath a giant piece of machinery
name: Pisces (LMD)

volume_credits.name: Avengers: West Coast Avengers - Sins of the Past
Avengers: The Once and Future Kang

deck: Part of the LMD Zodiac team.
description:
After the destruction of both previous male versions of Pisces, Scorpio created a female Pisces. She arranged the ambush in which the android Zodiac killed all of the remaining human Zodiac leaders except Cornelius van Lunt, alias Taurus. Immediately afterward, Van Lunt sought out the services of the Avengers' West Coast branch to confront and defeat the android Zodiac. In their initial foray, the Avengers failed, although several androids were destroyed.

The Zodiac Key immediately resurrected the Scorpio LMD. Claiming superiority and believing that the Zodiac would eventually kill the Avengers as the androids could never be stopped, Scorpio wanted to use the Key to transport everyone on the scene to the Key's native dimension where the conflict, he believed, could be prolonged indefinitely. However, when the androids were in the other dimension, they ceased to function because each of them were aligned with a particular zodiacal energy, energy that did not exist in the other dimension. The Avengers found Hawkeye and Tigra had been sent to the same dimension and, reunited, the team was sent back to Earth by the Brotherhood. However, secretly the Brotherhood waited so that someday they could also send the Key to Earth again and create new conflicts for them
name: Pisces (Female LMD)

volume_credits.name: Avengers: West Coast Avengers - Zodiac Attack

deck: Jodi Melville was one of the meteor freaks of Smallville. She had a crush on Pete Ross and was obsessed with becoming thin. After she drunk a few nutrient shakes laced with green kryptonite, she gained the ability to suck the fat from the bodies of humans and animals. Jodi is native to the TV series "Smallville".
name: Jodi Melville

deck: A woman who works for Ogilvy in his bid to become Emperor Penguin.
description:
Detective Comics

After getting in touch with a contact that was embedded in the Gotham City Police Department, she reported to Ogilvy that Batman was trying to convince others that not all the killings from the previous night had been Joker related. He seems unbothered by the news and is more concerned with the word on the street where his enemies still believe that the murders were committed by the Joker and his fanatics.

first_appeared_in_issue.name: The Pursuit of Happiness; Doctor's Orders

issue_credits.name: The Pursuit of Happiness; Doctor's Orders

name: Ms. Finch

deck: Dr Annabelle Riggs is an archaeologist that specializes in obscure objects.
description:
History

Dr. Annabelle Riggs grew up watching too many Indiana Jones-like movies and decided to become an archeologist herself. She has apparently known Misty Knight for quite some time, and the museum that she works for keeps Knight on retainer. She recently hired Misty to acquire various artifacts and the Daughter of the Dragon had a rocket shot at her for her trouble. Annabelle was looking at an archeological dig on what appeared to be a statue when she accidently activated it. The statue began emitting a song in a foreign language that the scientist did not recognize. In a matter of moments, the dead vikings that were buried in the ground rose and began attacking everyone at the dig site. Valkyrie, drawn by the song, arrived and aided Misty in fending off the undead horde. Annabelle, a lesbian, was immediately smitten by the swordmaiden. When Valkyrie noticed the statue, she had the doctor hand it over; Valkyrie destroyed the statue, much to the archeologist's dismay.

In exchange for destroying the statue, Dr. Riggs insisted that Valkyrie take her with her on her mission. The Asgardian initially rejected this out of concern for the human's well-being, but Annabelle stood her ground and so, Valkyrie reluctantly agreed to allow both Annabelle and Misty Knight to accompany her.

Annabelle travels with Valkyrie and Misty to Asgardia and along the way learns that she is not the first man or woman to kiss Valkyrie and that she thought nothing of it (much to Annabelle's disappointment). On Asgardia, she meets with The All Mother (Freyja, Gaea, and Idunn). As Valkyrie reports to the All Mother the meeting is interrupted by Hela. Hela chastises Valkyrie and beats Misty up for daring to attack her. Annabelle prepares to heft Valkyrie's sword in her defense but is stopped by Hippolyta, Hela's personal Warrior Woman.

Annabelle is killed while trying to stop Valkyrie, who has found out that she was one of the original Doom Maidens. Valkyrie was the Maiden of Rage. Annabelle manages to return Valkyrie to her sense, but not before she is killed.

Valkyrie feels intense grief over her death and with the help of Clea, a former Defender, returns Annabelle to life.There is a catch, however. Valkyrie and Annabelle now share one body. They switch back and forth between the two.

Annabelle develops a relationship with Ren, an Inhuman, whose powers are awakened by the Terrigen bomb. Ren joins the Fearless Defenders.

Creation

Dr. Annabelle Riggs is a Marvel comic book character created by Cullen Bunn and Will Sliney, first appearing in the 2013 series Fearless Defenders, in the very first issue.
name: Annabelle Riggs

volume_credits.name: Fearless Defenders: The Most Fabulous Fighting Team of All

deck: He is a living sock that hates Ambush Bug and has a Doctor Doom-like complex and mask.
description:
Origin

Brum-El (thinking his planet, Schwab, was going explode) launched his wardrobe into space. A giant, radioactive spider destroyed it, but the Ambush Bug suit and a sock survived. The sock became alive due to the radiation. Irwin Schwab found the suit and took it. The sock wandered the streets alone. After being mauled by a cat, the sock entered a lab and mastered its technology. He built himself a mask and became Argh!Yle! to get revenge on Ambush Bug for abandoning him.

Schemes

Argh!Yle! gained an army of living socks and a space station (which looked like a wardrobe). He captured Ambush Bug and trapped him in a giant diaper. Then, he threw the diaper to Earth.

He tried to kill Ambush Bug with the "Plan of Steel", which involve a copy of Superman's shoe. DC Comics blew up Argh!Yle! for violating their copyright of the character.

In Ambush Bug: Year None, Argh!Yle! sent minion socks to defeat Ambush Bug, but is arrested.

Powers

In a parody of Who's Who, it was claimed he had the powers of "the Legion of Super-Heroes' socks", but this is never shown or expanded upon.

He has genius-level intelligence.
name: Argh!Yle!

deck: Without her help Ryuhou would not know the truth and would not help to protect the land-lost friend Kazuma and Kanami Yuta.

The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

deck: Wealthy retired CEO of the Vanger Corporation. Still mourns the passing of his niece Harriet.
description:
Origin

Henrik Vanger is a very wealthy patriarch, and former CEO of the Vanger Corporation. Now in his twilight years, his attention has turned to a long dark family secret that tears away at his conscious: the murder and abduction of his most adored niece some 40 years prior, Harriet Vanger. Despite trying to put that terrible incident behind him, every year he is haunted by her memory with her killer taunting Henrik by sending him a pressed flower portrait every year on the same day, much like his niece Harriet use to, before her death. With vast resources at his disposal, he hires Mikael Blomkvist and Lisbeth Salander to solve the mystery of her death. He is assisted often by his housekeeper Anna Nygren.

Creation

Henrik Vanger is a fictional character created by novelist and journalist Stieg Larsson for his book series Millennium. The character would be portrayed in several movies, as well as eventually making his way to graphic novels.

Character Evolution

The character of Henrik Vanger has had limited character development as per his role as a secondary character, despite many of the most important plot details of the first story revolving around his family and him.

Major Story Arcs

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

Henrik has received another framed flower pressing, the forty second in as many years. This spurns the wealthy former tycoon to hire Mikael Blomkvist to solve the mystery.

Powers and Abilities

Henrik Vanger possesses no extraordinary powers or abilities, and has the fitness level of someone in their eighties. Vanger is extremely wealthy, the former founder and CEO of Vanger Corporation, and even owns islands.

Other Media

Movies

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

Novel

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2005)

issue_credits.name: Les hommes qui n'aimaient pas les femmes - Première partie

movies.name: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

name: Henrik Vanger

volume_credits.name: Stieg Larsson's The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo Special
The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

deck: A investigative journalist and co-owner of the monthly magazine Millennium.
description:
Origin

After graduating from the School of Journalism Mikael Blomkvist would go on to become a top Swedish investigative journalist, and co found and editor of Millennium magazine. Through his work with Millennium magazine, a political journalistic publication Blomkvist would find himself in hot water after losing a libel case against wealthy businessman Hans-Erik Wennerström. His new work would lead him to meet another wealthy businessman Henrik Vanger offering a chance of redemption, and a young strange computer hacker Lisbeth Salander. Mikael also enjoys an intimate relationship with co owner of Millennium magazine Erika Berger.

Creation

Mikeal Blomkist is a fictional character created by writer Stieg Larsson for his book series Millennium. The books success has garnered its own movie adaptations as well as its own graphic novel series, released by Vertigo. Writer Denise Mina and artist Leonardo Manco will be fulfilling the creative duties for The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo graphic novel adaptation. The character himself is loosely based on another fictional Swedish character, the boy detective Bill Bergson.

Character Evolution

Often overshadowed by his co star Lisbeth Salander in later stories, much of the main plot of the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo revolves around Mikeal Blomkvist, and his fall from grace to uncovering a deep dark murder mystery.

Major Story Arcs

Fall from Grace

Blomkvist is coming off a losing court case and facing public scandal and pressure. His partially owned Millennium magazine is facing financial loss from the controversy and scandal. Mislead by a source he trusted, Blomkist now faces jail time, a hefty fine and a ruined career. In a twist of good fortune he would be approached by a man representing Henrik Vanger with an offer and job opportunity. Blomkvist would be hesitant and run through the scenario in his mind as well as run over what taking this job may mean for his social life, family life and affect his business/magazine. He would talk over the opportunity with coworker and lover Erika Berger. He would explain how his presence is hurting Millennium and how he should quit at least for a while to give Millennium a better chance to recover. Not only that but Blomkvist is informed by Vanger's associate that by accepting this new job offer theyw ould give him more than enough evidence to incriminate Wennerström and clear his name.

Powers and Abilities

Mikael Blomkvist possesses no inherent super powers or abilities, he is just an ordinary human with average fitness. Blomkvist does possess above average intelligence and articulation. He is a investigative journalist.

Other Media

Movies

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

Mikael Blomvist is portrayed by actor Daniel Craig.

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

Mikael Blomkvist is played by Swedish actor Michael Nyqvist.

The Girl Who Played with Fire (2009)

Mikael Blomkvist is once again played by Swedish actor Michael Nyqvist.

The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets' Nest (2009)

Mikael Blomkvist is once again played by Swedish actor Michael Nyqvist.

Novel

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2005)

The Girl Who Played with Fire (2006)

The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets' Nest (2007)

deck: A character from Belly Button Comix.
description:
Origin

Eddy is an anthropomorphic bear from the Fantagraphics title Belly Button Comix.

Character Evolution

Eddy lives with his parents, but is very unhappy at home. One night he decides to run away. He soon finds out that being independent is a lot more difficult than it seems. While on the run he meets a female bear at a bar. The two start talking, and Eddy takes the girl home.

Major Story Arcs

Eddy does not appear in any major story arcs.

Powers and Abilities

Eddy has no special powers.
name: Eddy Bear

deck: Member of the "New" Zodiac, organized by "World Trust" Scorpio.
description: Carries a staff as a weapon. He was later killed by Zodiac and he made a hunting trophy out of his head.
name: Aries (Brandauer)

deck: Part of Ecliptic's Zodiac team.
description: He had superhuman strength, horns, and used a gun. Aries was a product of genetic engineering recruited by Scorpio who was working for the Ecliptic. This version of Zodiac was sent by Scorpio to steal the Nth Projector from Department H. During their mission they were attacked and defeated by Alpha Flight, but were able to escape. Aries was one of several Zodaic members who released a bacterial super-organism which killed Sasquatch. Soon after, the Director of Weapon X sent a Weapon X team to the Zodiac's castle headquarters to retrieve Madison Jeffries who had become one of the Zodiac's Gemini twins. The Zodiac were defeated and Jeffries was recovered. The Zodiac were drained of their life energy by Sauron and, after the creature had left, Weapon X blew up the castle leaving the Zodiac for dead
name: Aries (Ecliptic's Zodiac)

deck: Created by Scorpio (Jake Fury) using the Zodiac Key to serve as members of his own Zodiac team.
description:
This version of Aries was a Life Model Decoy created along with an entirely new Zodiac team created by Scorpio (aka Jake Fury) using the Scorpio Key. During the battle Moon Knight and Nighthawk were able to cause Aries to slam into a wall knocking it unconscious. The Aries LMD was taken into S.H.I.E.L.D. custody following the battle.

Later, Aries and the rest of the LMD Zodiac, led by Quicksilver, battled the Avengers whom Quicksilver was attempting to frame for treason. During an underwater battle near Avengers Mansion with a team of the heroes, the Aries and Taurus LMDs were flung out into the river and apprehended by the authorities

deck: Created by Scorpio (Jake Fury) using the Zodiac Key to serve as members of his own Zodiac team.
description:
Cancer was a Life Model Decoy created by Scorpio (Jacob Fury) in his "Theatre Of Genetics" to be part of his Zodiac crime organization. Scorpio went after his brother, Nick Fury, with his new group, but was defeated by Defenders and Moon Knight. The Zodiac LMD's were recruited by Quicksilver during his bout with temporary insanity, and Quicksilver ordered the Zodiac LMD's to destroy Avengers for their imagined wrong doings. The Avengers managed to defeat the group and most were remanded into federal custody.

The android Zodiac were soon released, and the Scorpio LMD rebuilt a number of them. Scorpio used the Zodiac Key to create LMDs that exemplified the forces and personalities inherent in each sign, hoping to create great strength in the combination of all twelve traits of the Zodiac. He arranged the ambush in which the android Zodiac killed all of the remaining human Zodiac leaders except Cornelius van Lunt, alias Taurus. Immediately afterward, Van Lunt sought out the services of the Avengers' West Coast branch to confront and defeat the android Zodiac. In their initial foray, the Avengers failed, although several androids were destroyed.

The Zodiac Key immediately resurrected the Scorpio LMD. Claiming superiority and believing that the Zodiac would eventually kill the Avengers as the androids could never be stopped, Scorpio wanted to use the Key to transport everyone on the scene to the Key's native dimension where the conflict, he believed, could be prolonged indefinitely. However, when the androids were in the other dimension, they ceased to function because each of them were aligned with a particular zodiacal energy, energy that did not exist in the other dimension. The Avengers found Hawkeye and Tigra had been sent to the same dimension and, reunited, the team was sent back to Earth by the Brotherhood. However, secretly the Brotherhood waited so that someday they could also send the Key to Earth again and create new conflicts for them.

This Cancer has enhanced strength and endurance and an armored shell that provides some protection from physical and energy attacks. He can project powerful jets of water from its hands and has a set of pincers which he can use as a weapon.

issue_credits.name: Who Remembers Scorpio? Part 3: Scorpio Must Die!

name: Cancer (LMD)

Cancer was more of a fill in character, said nothing and was mostly behind the scenes. He was killed with the rest of the Zodiac by Weapon X.

deck: Expert computer hacker, and friend of Lisbeth Salander.
description:
Origin

A large overweight recluse, Plague identifies more with his hacker name than his birth name. Plague is an associate of Lisbeth Salander also a fellow hacker, and the two could be described as having a friendship, something neither have an excess of. Plague is known to help Lizbeth out with computer and tech problems now and then. On one occasion Plague with the assistance of Mikael Blomkvist even assisted Lisbeth as she was under arrest and in hospital.

Creation

Plague appears in the graphic novel The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, released by Vertigo adapted and based off the novel series Millennium by Stieg Larsson. The character also appears in the original book series and the numerous movie adaptations.

Powers and Abilities

Plague has no superhuman powers and abilities. Although large and out of fitness, Plague is an incredible computer expert and infamous as one of the worlds best hackers.

Other Media

Novels

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2005)

Plaque has a minor role in the first Millennium novel written by Stieg Larsson.

The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets' Nest (2007)

Plaque has another miner role in the sequel to The Girl Who Played With Fire, assisting Lisbeth who is being kept under confinement in hospital.

Movies

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

In the Americanized movie adaptation of the Millennium book series Plague is portrayed by Tony Way.

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

A movie adaptation of the Millennium book series Plague is portrayed by Tomas Köhler.

The Girl Who Kicked the Hornets' Nest (2009)

The third and final chapter of the movie adaptations of the Millennium book trilogy Plaque is portrayed by Tomas Köhler.

movies.name: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

name: Plague

volume_credits.name: Stieg Larsson's The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo Special
The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

deck: Editor in chief of Millennium magazine.
description:
Origin

Co owner, public relations manager and editor in chief of Swedish political magazine Millennium. Although she is married to Greger Beckman she is engaged in a steady romantic and sexual relationship with Mikael Blomkvist. After scandal forces Mikael to step down, Erika continues to try and provide emotional support for him as he takes on a special and unique investigation on bequest of Henrik Vanger.

Creation

Erika Berger is a fictional character who first appears in the Millennium novel series The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, released in 2005. Written by Swedish author and journalist Stieg Larsson, the book and its sequels have spawned much success, including movies and a graphic novel released in 2012 by Vertigo. Denise Mina and Leonardo Manco are the creative team responsible for adapting Girl with the Dragon tattoo into graphic novel format.

movies.name: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo

name: Erika Berger

volume_credits.name: Stieg Larsson's The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo Special
The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo

name: Scorpio (LaPoint)

story_arc_credits.name: Daredevil vs. Punisher: Means and Ends

deck: The crime-boss sister of the Suicide Squad member Yo-Yo.
description:
Storyline

Min Jie-Ru is a character introduced in the New 52, and is the brother of Chang Jie-Ru (Yo-yo), who is a member of the Suicide Squad.

Min spent her life trying to make the best life she could for herself, treating the sacrifice that her father made through a life of crime with utmost reverence. However, her brother Chang represented the opposite side of that coin. Whereas Min concentrated on study, achievement and her career as a scientist, Chang took up their father's line of work. What more, Chang was constantly coming to Min with requests for money, and other resources to help bail him out of the danger that he had placed himself in through his nefarious activities.

Eventually, Min worked her way onto the most elite staff of the Metropolis University, overseeing a lab whose experiments were centered around a geothermal reactor that could potentially power Metropolis forever. It was while her and Chang were in the room with this reactor that a battle Superman was having in Metropolis encroached on the University. Min was in the process of hurriedly shutting down the reactor when the chaos from the fight above fractured its shell, and both siblings were caught in the ensuing explosion.

From that point onward, Min and Chang became decisively estranged - maintained by Min's refusal to associate with her brother. Some years later, through happenstance Chang had become a member of Amanda Waller's Suicide Squad as the elastic Yo-yo. Chang was chosen to lead an assignment that included retrieving Min from the Tang Yan Fau in Chinatown. When the team reached the penthouse, it wasn't to find the Min that Chang remembered. She had been strangely morphed, and possessed bizarre powers centered around her new, plant-like physiology.

Not only that, but Min was working under the supposedly deceased Regulus, and going by the name Red Orchid.

Powers and Abilities

Red Orchid appears to have an altered, plant-based physiology that allows the emission of airborne toxins and paralytics. She can also loose poison-laced thorns from her body with explosive force.
name: Red Orchid

volume_credits.name: Suicide Squad: Death Is For Suckers

The Zodiac are a group of ambitious people who wanted to conquer the World by stealing different powerful items and taking them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos.

description: The new Zodiac team, are a group of ambitious people who want to conquer the World. Pisces wears a special suit supplied by Thanos that enables him to assume a fish-like appearanceand gives him super-powers. Thanos wanted them to steal different powerful items and take them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos. He was one of the Zodiac members who attacked the Helicarrier in order to retrieve an Ultimate Nullifier and he was left powerless when Iron Man used a sonic disruptor to shut down their special costumes and leave them powerless.

Thanos wanted them to steal different powerful items and take them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos.
name: Sagittarius (Thanos' Zodiac)

deck: Member of Thanos' new Zodiac team.
description: Leo is one of the members of the new Zodiac team, a group of ambitious people who wanted to conquer the World. Leo wears a special suit supplied by Thanos that enables him to assume the form of a humanoid lion and gives him super-powers. Thanos wanted the Zodiac team to steal different powerful items and take them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos. He was one of the Zodiac members who attacked the Helicarrier in order to retrieve an Ultimate Nullifier, while battling the Hulk, he suffered a heart attack and died, the energy of his suit passed through Iron Man's armor, which helped him to known where Zodiac had their powers from and shut them down.

deck: Capricorn is a member of Thanos' new Zodiac team.
description: The new Zodiac team, are a group of ambitious people who wanted to conquer the World using special suits supplied by Thanos which gives them super-powers. Thanos wanted them to steal different powerful items and take them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos.

deck: Aquarius is a member of Thanos' new Zodiac team.
description: Aquarius and the Zodiac are group of ambitious people who want to conquer the World. They use special suits supplied by Thanos which gives super-powers. Thanos wanted them to steal different powerful items and take them out from Earth in order to bring balance to the planet and the cosmos. He was sent to intercept a mysterious object from the U.S. Army in the desert. Hulk tried to stop him, but was ineffective. Aquarius left the scene with the mysterious object. He was one of the Zodiac members who attacked the Helicarrier in order to retrieve an Ultimate Nullifier and he was left powerless when Iron Man used a sonic disruptor to shut down their special costumes and left them powerless. Aquarius possesses the ability to bodily transform himself in whole or in part, into liquid.
name: Aquarius (Thanos' Zodiac)

aliases:
Detective Inspector Ransom
The Big Stiff
deck: British policeman on secondment to U.S. police, whose large frame, choice of outfit (suit and bowler hat) and soft spoken manners fooled many of his new colleagues into thinking him a dim oaf, rather than the sharp-witted detective he truly was.
description:
Origin

Because of his deceptively awkward appearance, Jim's American colleagues had nicknamed him "The Big Palooka"

Sergeant Jim Ransom was a Scotland Yard detective who was sent to the United States, initially New York, to learn American crime-fighting techniques. His appearance led his new partner, Sergeant Joe Rooney, to immediately write Ransom off as a "big palooka", but Joe was soon proved wrong, as Ransom, an ex-Royal Marines Commando shooting instructor and war hero, was one of the sharpest, fairest and most fearless police men Britain had ever produced.

Creation

Jim Ransom debuted as "The Big Stiff", the titular lead of a text series in The Wizard. At this point a Detective Sergeant in the British CID (Criminal Investigation Department), his initial series started in Wizard 1699 on 6th September 1958 and ended with issue 1715 on 27th December 1958. He returned for three additional series, The Big Stiff In Chicago (1960), The Hoods Are Here! Further exploits Of The Big Stiff (1962) and The Big Stiff In The Amazing Mystery 'The Killers Of Kelmira' (1962).

In February 1965 Ransom transferred to New York and to comic strip format, and gained a new nickname, the Big Palooka, as he joined The Hornet starting from issue 75. The first installment also revealed that he had been a British Commando during World War II, and, though only 18 at the time, had been a shooting instructor training newly arrived US forces.

Subsequent series would see Jim transfer to Chicago, and then back to London, where, promoted to Detective Inspector, he led a taskforce dealing with American gangsters who have set up shop in London. After Hornet merged into Hotspur, the series went back in time to Jim's World War II exploits, showing his work as a training sergeant, then as a Commando, and finally depicting his recruitment into SIDAP (Special Investigation Dept Allied Powers), which led in turn to his police career.

With Jim's adventures having run intermittently until the late 1970s, the start of the 1980s saw him now a Police Commissioner, and had his series replaced by a spin-off, The Son of the Big Palooka, starring (no surprises here) his son Detective Sergeant Dave Ransom, a member of elite Criminal Intelligence Unit C18.

It was Chess Roberts who presented some news reports about the opening of the Stark Expo.

deck: A new mutant recruited in San Diego by Cyclops' revolutionary X-Men. His mutant power appears to revolve around strange bouncing balls that he expels from his body.
description:
Origin

A young man from San Diego, California, Fabio's new mutation emerges after someone attempts to rob him. The odd, bouncing balls that shoot from his body cause panic around him and the police attempt to arrest him. Cyclops, and his team of X-Men, arrive to defend him. Though the team is attacked by Sentinels, they are able to whisk Fabio away to his new life as a mutant.

Creation

Fabio was created by writer Brian Michael Bendis and artist Chris Bachalo. He first appeared in the story "The New Revolution" in Uncanny X-Men Vol.3 issue 1(2013).

Major Story Arcs

The New Revolution

After being recruited by Cyclops, the new mutants get to know each other better. They are soon sucked into Limbo by Dormammu and Fabio is scared, as well as the other new mutants. Thanks to the Cuckoos, Fabio and the rest are forced into a feeling of bravery as they battle for their survival. After Illyana absorbs Limbo and sends the X-Men out of the dimension, Fabio cries to go home. Fabio is allowed to leave and Emma and Scott escort him home where he reunites with his family and shows them he is a indeed a mutant. Not long after this revelation, the mutant Dazzler enters their house and questions Fabio to tell her where Cyclops is. Dazzler kidnaps Fabio and interrogates him on a S.H.I.E.L.D. helicarrier, but he refuses to tell her much of anything and it isn't long before Cyclops' team invades the helicarrier and rescues Fabio.

He re-dedicates himself to his training with the team and to it's mission. He becomes so dedicated that when Scott Summers loses heart, Fabio erupts in a rage, seemingly killing Scott with his balls. It is his teammate Triage that heals Scott.

End of the Revolution

After Cyclops had disbanded the New Xavier School, the students, rather than joining the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning, band together to form an unaffiliated team of super heroes. In their first outting the team once again faced off against one of their first threats, a young mutant named Animax. In an outburst against her abusive father Animax had psychically summoned an army of monsters to terrorize a highschool where he worked as a football coach. As the team arrived in a jet controlled by Hijack, the mutants quickly set out to stop her. With Morph (Deeds)talking her down and the Stepford Cuckoos holding back her assault, Goldballs used his ability to knock her out. All of this was captured via cellphone camera and blew up overnight as the mutants quickly became famous. Fabio was called by his parents who proudly spoke about their son on live TV, but the fame didn't stop there. From talk-shows to magazine covers, the team became more loved with every villain they fought, which ranged to even the likes of defeating Klaw.

It wasn't until the world learned from Fabio's parents that he was a mutant, that things would quickly change. After defeating yet another villain, Goldballs expected praise from the onlooking crowd only for a glass bottle to be thrown at the young hero, leaving shards of broken glass stuck in his neck. While the Cuckoos drove off their attackers psychically, Triage and Morph went on to help heal Fabio's near fatal injury before they fled. Learning the hard way that despite their good intentions that their mutant gene would still be hated, Hijack brought them to the Jean Grey School for Higher Learning, knowing that they would have a lot to learn still about being accepted.

Powers & Abilities

Fabio has the mutant ability to project solid gold balls from his body. They leave his body with an audible "poink"! While it is unknown if these balls are actually composed of metal or gold, they are highly durable and not prone to popping or bursting. The balls seem to be able to bounce and he can project them from any part of his body at any size. They fly at high speeds and he is able to summon up an infinite amount in order to attack his enemies. Given the chance to concentrate, he can direct them in a specific area or project them in a straight line.

After much training, he can properly control the amount or frequency at which he summons them. For example, he was able to knock a gun away from an enemy with one directed ball. However, in times of stress and anxiety he often leaves the battleground covered in scattered balls that endanger both enemies and allies. When he calms himself and dismisses them, the gold balls vanish completely, having no need to reabsorb them back into his person.

Fabio has learned a small degree of self defense from the New Xavier School, most likely various forms of martial arts. Now he eagerly shouts out the name "Goldballs!" in activation of his power.

deck: A character from Trucker Fags In Denial
description:
Origin

Butch appears in the Fantagraphics one-shot, Trucker Fags In Denial.

Creation

Butch was created by Jim Goad and Jim Blanchard.

Character Development

Butch is a long distance truck driver who spends most of his time with his friend and coworker Petey. Butch is the more aggressive, assertive and dominant friend of the two. Both friends are extremely bigoted, toward homosexuals in particular. Early on, Butch tells Petey that he once killed a man for making advances toward him. The man was a fellow driver, and Butch had been paired up with him for a job. Butch explains that the man put his hands on him, squeezing his leg, and that Butch lost his temper and stabbed the man to death with an ice pick. He also claims to have dumped the body in the Louisiana bayou.

While on the road together, Butch and Petey end up spending a night in the same room at a hotel. Over the course of this night the pair have sex several times, only to wake up feeling awkward and full of shame in the morning. After spending all day avoiding the subject, with tensions mounting between the pair, Butch and Petey attack each other. They are then arrested and thrown in jail, where they take advantage of their shared cell and resume their sexual activities from the previous night. In spite of their physical intimacy with each other, the pair vehemently deny - both aloud and in private - that they are homosexual. Instead they rationalise their actions, and appease their consciences by going on a violent spree, killing any homosexual men they encounter while still enjoying a sexual relationship with each other.

Major Story Arcs

Butch does not appear in any major story arcs.

Powers and Abilities

Butch does not have any special abilities.
name: Butch

deck: A character from Trucker Fags In Denial
description:
Origin

Petey appears in the Fantagraphics one-shot, Trucker Fags In Denial.

Creation

Petey was created by Jim Goad and Jim Blanchard.

Character Development

Petey is a long distance truck driver who spends most of his time with his friend and coworker Butch. Petey is the more sensitive, patient, submissive one of the two friends. Both friends are extremely bigoted, particularly toward homosexuals. Petey reveals that this is because when he was a child, after his parents were sent to prison, he was sexually abused by his therapist.

While on the road together, Butch and Petey end up spending a night in the same room at a hotel. Over the course of this night the pair have sex several times, only to wake up feeling awkward and full of shame in the morning. After spending all day avoiding the subject, with tensions mounting between the pair, Butch and Petey attack each other. They are then arrested and thrown in jail, where they take advantage of their shared cell and resume their sexual activities from the previous night. In spite of their physical intimacy with each other, the pair vehemently deny - both aloud and in in private - that they are homosexual. Instead they rationalise their actions, and appease their consciences by going on a violent spree, killing any homosexual men they encounter while still enjoying a sexual relationship with each other.

Major Story Arcs

Petey does not appear in any major story arcs.

Powers and Abilities

Petey does not have any special abilities.
name: Petey

name: Danny Oneman

deck: Goldbug is a Courier Officer of the Throttlebots in the IDW Transformers Continuity.
description:
Origin

Goldbug is an officer of the Autobot's reconnaissance team the Throttlebots. His small size makes him perfect to be a scout and courier for the team.

For the Original G1 Goldbug see Bumblebee

Creation

Goldbug was created for the IDW Transformers Continuity and was first seen in Spotlight: Metroplex by writer Andy Schmidt and editor Denton J. Tipton. Goldbug existence was the decision of Schmidt to make the IDW version of Goldbug a character who is separate from the IDW version of Bumblebee. This Goldbug is the IDW universe's counterpart to the Goldbug of other Generation 1 universes, except that he and Bumblebee co-exist.

Major Story Arcs

IDW Continuity

Spotlight: Metroplex

Goldbug and the Throttlebots were assigned to Orvus Base, orbiting Salvvatan VI, to safeguard top-secret Autobot research. Their purpose was to act as couriers in case the lab came under threat, taking the data and keeping it out of enemy hands. When Sixshot attacked the facility, the Throttlebots were the only ones who made it out of the station alive, along with the research information.

They escaped Orvus Base but crashed on Salvvatan VI and quickly found for cover from Sixshot. The planet appeared to be unoccupied, with the exception of a Cybertronian-style city with energon reserves. As they were refueling, Sixshot caught up with them and demanded the research information. Goldbug stated they might not have the information, and asked if he would still torture them. Sixshot said he would, so Goldbug ordered the Throttlebots to scatter.

Sixshot quickly took down half the team, even as they tried to counterattack. Goldbug and the remaining two Throttlebots tried to distract Sixshot and then attacked him. The battle eventually took them into a chamber where an "intruder alert" was activated. As the fight continued Sixshot shot Goldbug point-blank in the chest.

As Sixshot was about to execute Searchlight, when the city around them awakened. A giant fist smashed Sixshot, followed by a similarly-proportioned foot. Goldbug and his two companions watched in awe at the city that had transformed into Metroplex. Metroplex declared his position had been compromised and announced that he was going to leave and go back into hiding. He told them where to find a shuttle and supplies. Goldbug upset that Metroplex was going to just leave, asked him what kind of Autobot would abandon them. Metroplex replied that he was sorry for them, but his mission was more important, and left.

Later Rollbar and Searchlight, who was carrying Goldbug, began walking back to recover their fallen teammates. They wondered how important Metroplex's mission must be and that he must be lonely.

Powers & Weaknesses

Goldbug is able to get up to 1.8 times more use out of his energon fuel. Goldbug is often called upon at times of low energy resources to perform scouting missions. His visual acuity rates tops of all Autobots, he can spot a 10"x10" object at a distance of 48 miles. His adaptability makes him particularly important in reconnaissance and salvage operations. His small size makes him perfect for missions that require somebody to go unnoticed. His size is also his greatest weakness. Goldbug is physically one of the weakest of the Autobots, and the easiest to damage. His stealth more the compensates for this liability.

Characteristics

  • Allegiance: Autobot
  • Sub Group: Throttlebots
  • Function: Courier/Scout
  • Alt-Modes: Cybertornian Car, VW Bug (Toy Only)
  • Color Schemes: Yellow/Black (IDW)
name: Goldbug

deck: A 1-Star Hunter and the examiner for the second phase of the Hunter Exam that Gon, Kurapika, and Leorio passed. She is a genius gourmet and the greatest Gourmet Hunter in the world.

deck: Isaac Netero is a character in the manga Hunter x Hunter by Yoshihiro Togashi. Isaac Netero is the previous Chairman of the Hunters' Association and was replaced by Cheadle Yorkshire after killed by the antagonist Meruem. He was also considered the second strongest character in the series.
description:
Powers and Abilities

Hyakushiki Kannon - This Nen ability takes the form of a Guanyin. In order to attack usomg the statue, Netero must first pray, the statue then strikes the opponent multiple times.

Ichi no Te - Netero performs a chopping motion and the statue mimics it.

San no Te - Netero performs a clapping motion and the statue mimics it.

Tsukomo no Te - Netero makes a sign with his hands that looks like the number ninety-nine. Afterward, the statue then hits the opponent multiple times with open palms.

Zero no Te - Netero first prays with all his heart. Looming from behind, the statue then howls an enormous flare of aura.
name: Chairman Netero

deck: The Mother of Amadeus Arkham. Having been mentally ill for years, Amadeus mercy killed her and repressed the memories for years after. Arkham Asylum was named after her.
description:
Creation

Elizabeth and the rest of the history of Arkham Asylum was first detailed in Who's Who: The Definitive Directory of the DC Universe  #1 written by Len Wein. 
She made her first panel appearance in Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth written by Grant Morrison and painted by Dave McKean, which was based on the original Who's Who entry by Len Wein.
